LATER --- The clan have gathered around Tergehl, the chil at his feet, eyes glimmering. Grasping a gnarled staff, Tergehl scratches his chin as i story he knows so well were difficult to recall. TERGEHL (CONT’D) Long, long ago, the world was very different. Giants walked the land. There were so many giants that you could not count them all even if you counted for your entire life. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These giants had enormous brains. They could speak to one another across great distances. They taught themselves to fly and traveled wherever they wished, even to the moon and the stars. Yet despite these great powers, the giants were not happy. They spoke in different tongues, worshipped different gods, and fought bitterly against one another. No matter how much they ate, the giants always wanted more. They killed all the animals, chopped down all the forests, fished all the seas. And their fires warmed the entire world, making it unbearably hot. As Tergehl continues, we are transported to --

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: Thank you, everyone. Thank you for coming today, but more importantly I want to thank you for your dedication and hard work these past many months. Smiles and applause. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) Now then. You have probably guessed that I have something very exciting to announce -- very exciting, indeed. (then --) It is time. A moment of hushed jubilation. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) No doubt the generations to come -- perhaps all of humanity -- will thank you for your bravery and commitment. But today each of you must ask whether you are truly ready to enter this new world, for there will be no turning back. So I ask you -- are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: For nearly a century the Edvardsen Institute has been one of the few truly visionary research organizations, working entirely without government or commercial sponsorship... INT. CONFERENCE CENTER - DAY Al4 Participants check-in at a REGISTRATION TABLE, sip coffee mingle with their colleagues. OUTSIDE AN AUDITORIUM -- A sign announces one of many mor presentations:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice belongs to conference president DR. PAOLO PEREI who addresses a crowded hall.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEREIRA
dialogues.text: ..-and today I’m sure you will agree they have far exceeded even their many impressive achievements of the past. It gives me great pleasure to welcome the director of the institute and my old friend Dr. Andreas Jacobsen, along with his colleague, Dr. Jorgen Asbjornsen. Dr. Jacobsen emerges carrying a wooden box which he sets the podium.

dialogues.speaker: DR. JACOBSEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dr. Pereira. Seventy-five years ago, Mrs. Nellie Edvardsen, overcome with guilt by the fortune her late husband’s family had amassed producing mustard gas during World War I, founded our institute so that the wonders of science could instead be used to help mankind. Our mission is to combat poverty, disease, natural disasters and other calamities that arise over time. In the 1950s, the institute identified over-population as mankind’s single greatest long-term threat, the source of all the catastrophes we are seeing today -- extreme climate and weather events, and the devastating impact on food and water security. Among the many solutions we conceived so many years ago, one which seemed then so ambitious, so outside our grasp, has at last borne fruit. Today we are proud to unveil what we fervently believe to be the only practical, humane and inclusive remedy to humanity’s gravest problem. Dr. Jorgen Asbjornsen will now present his findings. Are you ready, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: (muffled, distant) I am ready. Jacobsen opens the front of the box to reveal -- DR. ASBJ®RNSEN, NOW JUST FIVE INCHES TALL. As this miniature human walks out onto the podium, gasps astonishment ripple throughout the room. Many stand to ge better look.

dialogues.speaker: DR. JACOBSEN
dialogues.text: Everyone, please take your seats. Please! As the audience quiets, Dr. Asbjgrnsen takes his place be a tiny podium, dons reading glasses, and removes a speech his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Pereira, esteemed colleagues. Five years ago, building on the research of our predecessors at the institute, my team and I discovered a process by which all organic material can be reduced at the cellular level by a ratio of approximately 2,744 to one. Such a process converts a man of 1.8 meters to just 12.9 centimeters. A wide array of flora and fauna were subjected to this process and, with the exception of some fish and shellfish, absolutely no side effects were detected. Please lights. The room dims. A GROUP PORTRAIT of the gathering at the Asbjernsen home appears on a screen above the stage -- th first image in a PowerPoint presentation. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) Once the safety of the procedure was confirmed, thirty-six brave volunteers joined my wife Anne-Helene and me as the very first humans to undergo cellular reduction. A NAKED SUBJECT poses before reduction, arms extended lik Vinci’s Vitruvian man. Next he shows off his new TINY BOD beside a metric a ruler held by enormous fingers.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: The exact science behind reduction itself falls outside of our discussion today, but the process is short and painless, with only the mild discomfort of removal and replacement of dental and other prosthetics. Now we see a RECOVERY ROOM where, wrapped in blankets, volunteers recline on miniature Le Corbusier lounges. One tiny man drinks from an enormous eye-dropper. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) Subjects are placed under light sedation, and after a brief rest, perhaps some crackers and applesdft, fully recover within an hour or two. Now a normal-sized SHORT-HAIRED DOG on a leash. The next slide shows the same dog standing next to the ruler while GIANT HAND restrains him with a tiny leash.  15 16

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: Of course, some of our community could not bear to leave behind their four-legged companions. Now shots inside a WORKSHOP. Volunteers construct small houses and buildings. Others sew tiny clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: As the subjects of our own study, our aim was not only to confirm the long- term viability of the process but also to investigate the social and psychological implications. Thus we set about to live together in the world’s very first self-sustaining community of the small. The next images show the building of a small VILLAGE. Gro members secure dollhouse-size dwellings onto foundations. we see the hoisting of a TRANSPARENT DOME over the new community. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) Once complete, our little village, just seven meters by eleven meters, was placed inside a gas-permeable enclosure designed to protect us from the hazards of weather, animals and insects.

We believe that with a timely embrace of miniaturization, our seemingly unconquerable problems of over- population, climate change, and insufficient food and water can become a thing of the past, and human life may safely thrive for millennia to come. dialogues.text: Yeah, that gets a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I wanted to be a surgeon, actually. I have small hands, which they say is a real plus. Hey, we might have wound up working together. You could’ve been my anesthesiologist!

dialogues.speaker: ANESTHESIOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Hey, how about that?  44 21

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wild. LATER -- Dinner has not yet begun. There’s still a fair 4 amount of mingling, but many are finding their chairs. Seated at his table, Paul takes a moment to look around, his eyes fall upon felt banners with inspirational saying “The door to happiness opens outward” and “The best way t find yourself is to lose yourself in service to others.” NEAR THE ENTRANCE a flurry of excitement suggests someone special has arrived. It’s just a GUY in his mid-20s, but judging from reactions -- gasps, pointing -- it’s the ACRYLIC BOX he carries that’s causing the commotion. The guy passes Paul and Audrey’s table and, like everyone else, they gawk at what’s inside the box -- A TINY COUPLE smiling and waving at old friends.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s Dave! Dave Johnson. And Carol. I heard he was coming but I had no idea... Man, I never would have pegged him for someone who'd go get small. Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: AT A TABLE
dialogues.text: The guy carrying the box -- Dave Johnson’s younger brothe ANDY -- sets it down and removes the top and front. Paul and Audrey join the onlookers, many of whom are taki photos with their phones. Dave and Carol walk out onto the table and speak through little hand-held MEGAPHONES.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, everybody! Hope we’re not intruding! Warm greetings all around. Dave places two tiny glasses w his brother can retrieve them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Andy, could you get Carol a... Honey, what’re you having?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Gin and tonic.  45 46 22

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: A gin and tonic, and for me... You know what? That sounds good. I/'11 have a gin and tonic, too. Andy slides the impossibly small tumblers onto his palm a heads toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With lime!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to do that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Just figure it out, okay? As many migrate toward the new arrivals, a JESUIT turns o mic at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: JESUIT
dialogues.text: Don’t mean to break up the party, but the silent auction closes in fifteen minutes, and there are still some very attractive items with no takers. EXT. FRIENDS’ HOUSE - NIGHT 45 A nice, middle-class home. INT. FRIENDS’ HOUSE - NIGHT 46 At this informal after-party for an extended group of old friends, the camera makes its way through the living room where little Carol Johnson holds court, standing on a cof table. Friends lean in to hear better.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We weren’t going to come at first, but then we started getting all the e- mails, plus my sister was having a lump removed. She’s fine, thank God, but I still needed to see her.

dialogues.speaker: SOME FRIEND
dialogues.text: So what’s traveling like? How’d you get up here from New Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, we flew. Airlines are getting more and more small-friendly. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They make it really easy, and all the seats are first class... We continue on to --

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN 47
dialogues.text: -- where Paul is amid a heart-to-heart with Dave, seated a box of Ak-Mak Crackers.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: So after a couple years in Florida, I moved out to Vegas and --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I remember. I think that’s about the last time we talked.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Vegas wasn’t such a good choice for me, as it turns out. Got into some real bad habits. Pretty much hit rock bottom.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Any other woman would have run for the hills, but Carol, man, she’s a saint. She stuck with me. But I really had to come clean about everything. And I mean everything. You know, almost.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And the decision to... (makes a shrinking motion)

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well, that’s the thing. We both needed a change. You know, start all over.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It must feel good knowing you’re making a real difference, too.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You mean all that crap about saving the planet? Downsizing is about saving yourself. Takes the pressure right off, especially money pressure. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just not, you know, driven and ambitious like the rest of my family. It’s not who I am. Now Carol and I, we live like kings -- a hell of a lot better than my brothers and my sister, I’ll tell you that. I send them pictures all the time, but they never respond.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, I’m still living in the same house I grew up in. Audrey’s dying for us to move, but we’re pretty strapped. Plus, my mom’s end-of-life care really took a toll. I mean, shit, I just finished paying off my student loans.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well, listen, if you ever start thinking about it seriously, here’s my two cents. There are lots of small communities cropping up out there, but don’t mess around. Leisureland’s where you want to be. They are a little pricier, but they were the first, and they’re still way ahead of the curve.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They’ve sure got a big marketing budget.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Lots to brag about. Best houses, best appliances, best doctors, they book all the big concert tours, got all the great restaurants. The kids love Cheesecake Factory and Leisureland’s got three of them. And I’m not just saying all this for the referral credit. (off Paul’s laugh) Hey, sorry, could you back up a little? I think there’s too much garlic in that salsa.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Or floss or something. I don’t know.  25 Suddenly a child’s SCREAM. Alarmed, Paul heads into the living room, where he finds the HOSTS comforting their fo year-old DAUGHTER, who has wandered downstairs and is sca out of her wits by the sight of little Carol.

dialogues.speaker: HOST MOM
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Katie. It’s okay. She’s a friend. She’s just smaller than we are, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hi, Katie! Hi! I won’t bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Audrey come in the door, exhausted but still buz about their unusual evening.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Well, that was sure interesting.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’l1l say.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I liked little Carol. She’s got a lot on the ball. She’s reading all the books she always wanted to, and she’s learning Italian. And she says she’s never been fitter.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They sure seem happy. Dave says he’s getting pretty good on the drums.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Next year they’re pulling the kids out of school to spend six months at a sister city in Tuscany. Cooking classes, yoga, wine-tasting, the whole nine yards.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (checking his phone) Uh-oh. Honey? Paul plays a message on speakerphone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICEMAIL
dialogues.text: Hi, guys. Milo here from Goodman Mortgage. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: VOICEMAIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hate to say it, but your application at First National bounced back. The underwriter didn’t like the adjustments in the appraisal. Like I said, the market for a hundred-year- old duplex with structural issues is pretty soft, and there are red flags from an underwriter’s perspective. I can try somewhere else, but frankly I think you’re going to need more cash up front if we want to get approved on the type of property you’re looking at. Paul and Audrey share a weighty, defeated look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Safraneks’ car zooms by a sign -- WELCOME TO NEW MEXI LAND OF ENCHANTMENT. A50 INT. PAUL’S CAR - DAY A50 As they drive --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I bet we’ll be able to tell right away if it’s for us or not.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Yeah, so let’s not waste time. Maybe could get to Santa Fe earlier and get a massage.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sounds good to me. Like we said, we're just checking it out. No harm, no foul. 50 EXT. PAUL’S CAR - NEW MEXICO HIGHWAY - DAY 50 Paul and Audrey’s car continues through the desert and pa a huge BILLBOARD.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT EXIT
dialogues.text: Tony Dale’s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across an immense parking lot sits a commanding building abuts a 20-foot-high WALL stretching in both directions, wall that encircles and safeguards the city of Leisurelan within. Long poles extending skyward from the wall support the ci protective overhead netting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Safraneks walk in, already starting to feel small in vast space. A huge banner shows an ecstatic couple -- “It like winning the lottery every day!” A large circular INFORMATION DESK is staffed by EMPLOYEES monogrammed golf shirts and khakis.

dialogues.speaker: AMONG THE EXHIBITS
dialogues.text: Audrey and Paul stroll through a maze of kiosks -- VACATI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Audrey sit watching a promotional movie.

dialogues.speaker: IN A TIDE POOL
dialogues.text: A horseshoe crab scuttles along, silent and primordial, passing a pair of rubber boots. Then we see the charismat man inside those boots.

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Tony Dale. That horseshoe crab has remained unchanged for 250 million years. Same size, same shell, same ugly mug. But we humans are different. We’re constantly evolving and adapting to new challenges. And today we find ourselves at the dawn of an exciting new chapter in human history. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Each and every one of you can be among the lucky ones to take this great leap forward, enjoy the prosperity you deserve, and, most importantly, help protect our precious planet. Join me, won't you, as we take a look at the creation of the world’s first luxury community designed entirely to make anyone’s biggest dreams come true -- Leisureland Estates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the copilot's seat, Tony turns around and speaks as th we’re in the back.

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE
dialogues.text: The first order of business was to find the perfect location -- not too cold in the winter, not too hot in the summer. No earthquakes, no tornados, no hurricanes. And no pesky mosquitoes. Yep, everything had to be just right. The pilot points out something below, and Tony raises binoculars to take a look.

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE UNITED STATES 56
dialogues.text: ZOOM in on New Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Our search led us to the ideal spot -- where we are right now -- ten square miles of high desert on New Mexico’s Vasquez Plateau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twine on surveyor’s stakes winds through cacti and scrub. In work clothes and sun hat, Tony paces out a distance, t stops and points broadly at the ground, giving confident directions to offscreen crew.  58 59 60 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACADEMICS give a presentation with charts and graphs. Ton sits up front nodding thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Next I gathered a team of top urban planners, architects and engineers from around the world to answer a simple question, “How can we design the most efficient and innovative city the world has ever known?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARCHITECTS AND ENGINEERS work at computers and drafting tables. Others build maquettes. ANOTHER ANGLE -- Wielding a pointer and surrounded by his team, Tony reviews an enormous tabletop model of Leisurel

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Each dwelling would be a dream house, a genuine estate within anyone’s reach. Mass transit would be free and efficient. The streets would be neat and orderly, offering easy access to shops, schools, parks, medical services, and of course all the recreation and entertainment you can imagine. Now RENDERINGS of different neighborhoods -- Alpine Villa New Orleans Quartier, Fairway Manors, The Marina.

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Each neighborhood would accent our residents’ interests, diverse lifestyles and hobbies. INT. TONY DALE’S OFFICE - DAY 60 Tony addresses us from behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: TONY DALE
dialogues.text: But no matter how much care we put into designing Leisureland, it’s really the people who make our community so special. So now I’d like to introduce you to some actual residents who are eager to tell you more.  61 30 As the movie ends, the screen begins to rise and Tony tur his gaze vaguely downward... TONY DALE (CONT’D) Okay, folks, take it away! .»-returning us to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stage lights illuminate, theme music begins, and a platfo thrusts past the rising screen. On the platform sits a downsized MANSION with swimming pool and tennis court. Tanned sales professional JEFF LONOWSKI steps out of the door wearing a headset mic, trailed by a tiny CAMERAMAN w transmits Jeff's image onto a large screen.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Dale. Welcome, everybody. I’m Jeff Lonowski, Senior Product Specialist and happy homeowner here at Leisureland Estates. Are you having a good time? (off initial response) Come on, guys. You’re a heck of a lot bigger than I am. Make some noise! Are you having a good time? Paul and Audrey join the enthusiastic response. “Yes!”

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s more like it. So what do you think of my place? Pretty nifty, huh? It’s the house of my dreams. Heck, I’d say it’s the house of anybody’s dreams. Why, an average guy like me might have to work twenty, thirty, even forty years to be able to afford a spread like this. And just wait until you see what’s inside. The house splits open to reveal the massive family room, enormous bedrooms, airy kitchen. In the master suite upstairs, and with a CAMERA GUY all her own, Jeff's “wife LAURA sits in a bubble bath.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (headset mic) Jeff, you’ve got to stop inviting guests over without telling me!  31

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Sorry, Laura. I was only --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I mean, I finally got in the tub to relax after such a busy day.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Busy doing what, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, no end of things. First I took a tennis lesson and had a massage. Then after a gourmet lunch with the girls, we just couldn’t help ourselves and popped into that new Loget’s store downtown.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Uh-oh, Loget’s. What’s that going to cost me?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Now, Jeff, you hush. I was really good. Just a diamond bracelet. The cameraman zooms in for a close-up of the sparkling jewelry, eliciting admiring “oohs” from audience members.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Just a diamond bracelet? That doesn’t sound like you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (pulling her hair back) And matching diamond earrings. And the matching diamond necklace. (as Jeff crosses his arms) Oh, Jeff, they look so good on me. Wait till you --

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: How much, Laura?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Now, Jeff --

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I said how much?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (sheepish) Sixty-two dollars.  62 63 64 32

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Sixty-two dollars? Are you crazy? Why, that’s practically our food budget for two whole months!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exit doors of the theater snap open. Along with the rest of the audience, Paul and Audrey step a wide walkway. Floor-to-ceiling windows offer a first glimpse at the actual city of Leisureland. The initial impression is both impressive and banal. It’s partially like a miniature theme park and partially like other mid-sized city. But a couple of unusual features stand out. One is a gian FERRIS WHEEL. Another is the CENTRAL TOWER, which functio both as a “tent pole” for the overhead netting and as the transfer station for an innovative and fanciful mass tran system -- GONDOLAS traveling on cables above the city. MOMENTS LATER -- Paul and Audrey peruse model homes rangi from one-story ranches through three-story McMansions -- Regency,” “The Barrington,” “The Aristocrat,” “The Mediterranean,” “The Sportsman.” At the top end, like a sumptuous Bel-Air estate, is “The Versailles,” boasting a sticker price of $129,999.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tracking shot through an ocean of sales desks ends on P and Audrey, where a chipper SALESPERSON walks them throug print-out of their finances.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: So putting it all together, if you liquidate your current home, vehicles and other assets, and purchase a Regency-level estate -- that’s a 12,000-square-foot-equivalent home on a 1.5-acre-equivalent lot -- at the base price of $63,000. Plus $4,500 for the Health and Fitness package. That’s the gym, pool, sauna/steam, hot tub, and tennis court. Then the medical procedure for two adults. That’s $15,000.  33

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Does insurance cover any of that?

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: No, but at Regency level you’re already qualifying for a substantial discount. And don’t forget the federal tax credit. So, figuring in your current debt, your retirement accounts and your savings, you’re looking at approximately $152,000 in equity, which is a very comfortable number.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Comfortable? That doesn’t sound like nearly enough.

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: You have to look at this column, Audrey. Equivalent value. You're solidly inside the Blue Chip zone. In Leisureland your $152,000 translates into around $12.5 million - - to live on, for life.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Hold on. If this is such a great thing, how come you haven’t done it?

dialogues.speaker: SALESPERSON
dialogues.text: I would in a heartbeat, but my husband had a hip replacement, so he’s ineligible. But look around you. If you come back in a month, you won’t see most of my co-workers still here. People take jobs just for the discount. Did you see Jeff's little show upstairs -- the house that opens up? He used to sit right over there. Of course, he doesn’t have to work anymore, but he’s a real ham -- just loves the attention. Anyway, how's all this sounding? Would the Regency be your first choice? Or should we be looking at something a little more deluxe? Audrey looks at Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Honey, pick anything you like. I just want you to be happy. She beams.  65 66 67 68 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Audrey oversee a RUMMAGE SALE of their belonging Downsizing! Everything Must Go!

dialogues.speaker: SOME OLD GUY
dialogues.text: How much for the hot dog cooker?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Four dollars.

dialogues.speaker: SOME OLD GUY
dialogues.text: I'll give you a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Sold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul finishes working with a FACTORY WORKER with a bad ar

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Keep up those exercises. Don’t get lazy. I laminated everything for you, so no excuses.

dialogues.speaker: FACTORY WORKER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Paul. Thank you so much. My wife and me, maybe someday we'll get small too and we’ll visit you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’d be great, but in the meantime... Paul squeezes and unsqueezes his hand, reinforcing an exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CO-WORKERS throw Paul a small goodbye party. Atop the cak a joke design in frosting about getting small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An emotional Paul walks to his car carrying a box of belongings. It’s the last time he’1ll ever see the place spent so many years.  69 70 71 35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perennially “hip” restaurant for the middle-aged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A farewell party occupies the back. Friends and family gather around four or five reserved tables. We catch snippets of conversations with different FRIENDS -- first is GINA.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I mean, sure, I was on the fence about it for most of the year. It’s pretty scary when you think about it at first. But then when my college roommate Patty Loomis called to say she and her husband were doing it, and all the reasons why, I turned to Paul and said okay, you win. Let’s go for it.

dialogues.speaker: GINA
dialogues.text: (hugging her) I’m just going to miss you so much.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Oh, Gina, I’m going to miss you too. But, you know, it’s not like we’re dying. We’re just relocating and changing things up a bit. We’ll be back at least once a year. And you and Tim can come down and stay with us anytime. We have like five guest rooms. Open invitation. Stay as long as you like. Gina laughs through tears at this joke. LATER -- BARRY talks with Paul and Audrey. 71

dialogues.speaker: BARRY
dialogues.text: And you guys didn’t consider Treasure Island out in Palm Desert?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, we checked it out, but... (looking at Audrey) I mean, I liked it all right, but Audrey thought they were a little stingy with the amenities, especially for what they charge in monthly maintenance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And too hot. And really provincial -- everything is golf, golf, golf. And almost no diversity. Super white bread.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, no diversity. 72 LATER -- Audrey’s father LARRY LUSTIG walks in. him with a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LUSTIG
dialogues.text: Your mother couldn’t bring herself to come, but she sends her love. We’re still expecting you tomorrow afternoon at the house. Paul arrives, and the men exchange a respectful

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Glad you made it, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What can I get you, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Let me. You guys visit.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LUSTIG
dialogues.text: Oh, just a beer. Any beer.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (exiting) Comin’ right up.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I wish Mom weren’t taking it so hard.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LUSTIG
dialogues.text: Well, you know your mother. To tell you the truth, I was pretty skeptical myself at first. You remember Jerry Gross. Well, I called him up the other day. He and Bev retired down there, did the whole shrinking thing you kids are doing. He says they’re getting along just fine, never better. Says he feels younger every day, says one dollar buys a thousand dollars worth of stuff. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 Audrey greets 72 handshake.  37

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LUSTIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course they need that with all the medication Bev takes. But yeah, they play nine holes every morning. Even taking a two-week cruise up to Alaska next month. First class stateroom, gourmet food, whole nine yards. Says the whole thing’s costing around $150. No, I see the appeal. And apparently there’s zero crime. That’s what I keep telling your mother. 73 LATER -- The party has wound down, and Paul and Audrey a final nightcap with close friends, including Tim, a fri of Paul’s we’ve met before. A DRUNK GUY wanders over.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK GUY
dialogues.text: Hey, you guys are getting small, right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s right. My wife and I.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK GUY
dialogues.text: My friend over there has a question. No offense, but do you think if you’re that small, you should still have all the same rights as the rest of us? Same right to vote?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t we?

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK GUY
dialogues.text: Well, let’s see. You’re not buying as many products, you’re not paying as much income tax, not really participating in our economy. In fact, you’re costing us money. And jobs.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. That’s enough. We’re all just having a good time here.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK GUY
dialogues.text: I’m just asking a simple academic question. If anything, a quarter- vote. At most.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (dragging him away) Come on, buddy. Let’s take a hike.  74 75 38

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK GUY
dialogues.text: I’m going. Or maybe an eighth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing by their cars in the nearly deserted lot, Audrey Paul give their friends a final farewell hug. INT. PAUL AND AUDREY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 75 All that remains is a mattress on the floor. Audrey sleep Paul reads by the dreary light of a sconce. Without warni she begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, honey. Her shoulders convulse. Paul pulls off his reading glasse

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honey, honey, I know. I know this is a big step. It’s the biggest thing we’ll do in our lives. I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything! You did this! Why did you have to choose such a stupid career? Why did you have to be so... unambitious? Helping people? What about helping yourself? What about helping me? You’re so goddamned stubborn! You did this!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey, that’s completely unfair. You’re the one who’s never satisfied with anything. You’re the one who says I spend too much time at work. You’re the one who wants to live in a palace. You’re the one who says we can’t have kids until we’re better off. You’re the one who hates her job and hates the cold weather and --

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I know! Don’t you think I know? Shut up! Shut up!  76 77 78 79 39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is bare. Audrey removes her necklace and places inside their Leisureland KEEPSAKE BOX, a shoebox-sized container for those few small irreplaceable treasures -- family photographs, jewelry, baby spoons, etc. Audrey gets Paul’s attention and points at her ring finge Together they remove their wedding rings and place them o velvet-covered stem inside the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey leans her head against Paul’s shoulder while he wa the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I keep thinking I forgot something. He kisses the top of her head.

dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. Wiping his hands, Paul hurries from t kitchen and greets pleasant but stiff KRISTEN SWANSON, wh holds a pie. She spots

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hi, Kristen.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Hi. I brought dessert. Apple- blueberry.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to do that. a huge yellow ROSE in a vase.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Wow, is that a real flower? Where’d you get that?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Full-Sized Flower Mart. Just opened. It’s like you’ve never seen a flower before.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful.  128 60

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I was tempted to get a lily, but, you know, it’d smell up the whole apartment. Plus the pollen. INT. PAUL’S DINING ROOM - NIGHT Paul and Kristen enjoy dinner.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Paul, this is so good.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks. The recipe called for chervil, but you can’t get chervil here yet. I used dill.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Well, whatever it is, it’s super- yummy .

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s the little things. I mean, except for no birds and insects you’d almost think we’re in the normal world. Then something happens, and you realize we’re not. Not that substituting dill for chervil’s a big thing, but you know. They smile and shake their heads. Life sure is strange.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Like last month when my parents came down to visit Jonah and me --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: -- and it’s like this whole production with the carrying boxes, and Jonah gets freaked out by Grandma and Grandpa being so huge and scary. One night they took us for dinner at Fleming’s, you know, real nice, and of course Jonah and I are sitting on the table in those special seats, and the big people wouldn't stop staring at us. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Plus, the restaurant brags about how small people are welcome, but then they charge a huge minimum.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They should be charging big people extra. They’re the ones dragging the world down.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: I know. Big people look at us like we're the freaks. They’re the freaks. I mean, sure, I brought Jonah here mostly for the schools, but I also know I’m at least trying to do something good. Oh, did you hear about all that gas being released in Antarctica? From the ice?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Haven’t really been following the news much lately.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, apparently it’s a big deal. A lot of scientists are saying we’re already way beyond -- Kristen is interrupted by a blast of EURO-DISCO thumping through the ceiling, followed by raucous LAUGHTER. Paul offers an apologetic grimace.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My upstairs neighbor. For months I don’t hear a peep -- I guess he wasn’t even here -- then suddenly it’s party, party, party. The other night I had to call Security. He wipes his mouth and heads toward his balcony.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Some Serbian guy. Businessman or something.  129

dialogues.speaker: A130
dialogues.text: 130 62 EXT. PAUL’S BALCONY - NIGHT 129 Paul reaches the railing and yells up toward the balcony above.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dusan! (pronounced “Dushan”) Hey, Dusan! EXT. DUSAN’S BALCONY - PAUL’S POV - CONTINUOUS A130 Euro-handsome DUSAN MIRKOVIC leans over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You mind turning down the music? Trying to have a quiet evening down here. Dusan gives Paul a little wave of “no problem.” Dusan's French girlfriend MARIETTE peeks over the railing, too.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. INT. PAUL’S DINING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER 130 The volume of the music is lower than before, but not muc Paul and Kirsten continue with their meal. For the moment neither can think of anything to say, so they simply eat exchange smiles. The doorbell. Paul gets up to open it.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Hello, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Dusan.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: May I come in? Once inside, Dusan gives Paul’s apartment a quick once-ov DUSAN (CONT’D) I’m sorry I am disturbing your nice little dinner, but listen, Pete --  63

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Paul. And Kristen.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Kristen. Like I was saying, I’m having one more, you know, little party at my place tonight. Justa few friends. Not big like last time. Very small. (noticing) No! Is that a rose? A real rose? From where you get a real rose?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: New store. Full-Sized Flower Mart.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Here in Leisureland? Why did I not have such a brilliant idea? How much they are charging for this?

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dusan! Dusan steps out onto Paul’s balcony and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Quoi, ma cherie?

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (French) Dusan, what are you doing down there? The caterers just arrived with the food and are asking where to put everything. I told them in the kitchen. Now they’re asking to be paid.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Oui, ma cherie. J’arrive. (back inside) Anyway, Paul, listen, if tonight noise disturbs you, just come upstairs and talk to me. Don’t make big show like last time yelling like crazy man. We are neighbors. And neighbors are friends. What’s better, come to the party.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thanks, but like I said, we’re just trying to have a nice, quiet dinner. So try to keep it down, okay?  131

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, darling. Of course. 64 Dusan puts a finger to his lips and makes a point of tip- toeing to the door, closing it without a sound.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Kind of a jerk, right?

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: What’s he even doing here? Aren't there like a ton of small cities in Europe? INT. PAUL’S HALLWAY - NIGHT Their date at an end, Paul walks Kristen down the hal Booming bass notes penetrate through the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, small party. (imitating) Just a few friends. Arriving at the elevator --

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for a really nice time. Plus, cooking and all. Sorry I have to leave so early, but, you know, the sitter. The elevator opens, and drunken SPANIARDS spill out.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: One floor up. They disappear back into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... Sunday. I was hoping we could bring Jonah. I'd like to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe. Paul leans in for a kiss. Kristen allows it, but her not in it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is something wrong? 131 lway. heart’s  132 133 134 65

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: No. I mean, you’re a wonderful guy, Paul, and I’ve really enjoyed hanging out with you...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (face darkening) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: ...-but if I’m honest about how I’m feeling, I just, well, I think it’s still a little early for me to --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Fine. I get it. Fine. Paul smacks the “down” button and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTEN
dialogues.text: No, Paul, listen, I only meant, if we're bringing Jonah into it --

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Have a good night. INT. PAUL’S CONDOMINIUM - NIGHT 132 Paul slams the door behind him and surveys the remnants o dinner. He picks up the leftover pie and throws it away, plate and all. Music and laughter crescendo upstairs. Paul looks at the ceiling. INT. DUSAN’S HALLWAY - NIGHT 133 Now lugging the huge rose, Paul exits the elevator and he toward the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul steps inside to find DOZENS OF PEOPLE -- various languages, fashionable eyewear, distinctive shoes. Dusan's chic apartment could not be more different from P with its double-high ceilings, wide doorways, fireplaces, furnishings. Feeling instantly out of place, Paul is about to leave.  66

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Paul! You came. And you bring the rose.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Peace offering.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Look, everybody. This is Paul, my neighbor. Look at what he brings me - - a real rose. A real fucking rose! (to Paul) Do you think any of these other ungrateful sons of bitches think to bring something to Dusan? Only you. I like you. What about your blonde American friend? Paul shakes his head. Dusan nods in approval. DUSAN (CONT’D) Why bring sand to the beach? (escorting Paul) Look, I know I said it was going to be a small party, but it’s not my fault. I make two or three phone calls to close friends, and look what happens. Everyone comes. Nothing else to do in this fucking city after 10 o’clock. This I do not understand. It’s not as if so many people have work in the morning. Is the worst trait of small people -- they are lazy. Not all, but most. Like this lazy guy. Konrad! KONRAD is an older German in nautical attire -- turtlenec double-breasted blazer -- helping himself to a splendid b of both normal-sized and small gourmet foods.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: What’s that you say about me? What lies are you telling?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Just that in the small world no one wants to work.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: What did you expect? That is the wonderful thing about becoming small. You are immediately rich. Unless you are very poor. Then you are only small.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Actually, I wouldn’t call myself poor, but I have a job --

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Konrad is sea captain. Never more than ten meters from his boat.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: I do like my boat. Come, I’11 show you. Locking arms with Paul and speaking with sudden intimacy, Konrad leads him onto --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Konrad points out a YACHT in the marina below.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: There she is -- Sonja, my beauty. An exact replica of an English yacht from 1927. You see, I am from many generations, all the way to my grandfathers and my father — all sea captains. I remember very well I was seven years old when my grandfather took me for the first time on his boat. I will never forget the rocking of the waves, the sound of the wind, the blackness of the water. From that moment I knew I would be a sea captain too.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What brings you to Leisureland?

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: Dusan. He even convinced me to become small, mostly for the women and the parties. And, frankly, my wife had all the money, so after she left, things became, let’s say, tricky.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can relate.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: It’s really quite wonderful to be small, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'd say it has its pluses and minuses.  135 68

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: I am here in your city about once a year, always with Dusan. Next week I will be in the Seychelles, and two weeks after that I’1l meet friends for a month of sailing on Lake Titicaca. Can you believe I’ve never been to Lake Titicaca?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wait, how do you get your boat from place to place? You can’t sail it.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: Fed-Ex, my boy. Sonja travels faster than I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul wanders around the party, an amiable smile on his fa He moseys into another room, where a handsome YOUNG MAN h court. A small group of party-goers surround him, hanging onto h every word and laughing at his jokes. Paul joins them, standing at the back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (to a guy) Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Who’s that? That’s Little Ronni.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Little Ronni?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: The first small baby ever born. You know, back in Norway.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Little Ronni? Holy shit. That’s Little Ronni? Paul gathers his courage and makes his way over to Ronni.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to interrupt, but are you really Little Ronni?  136 69

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RONNI
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not so little anymore, but yes, that’s me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wow. Would you mind if I got a picture? Paul holds out his phone for a selfie. Little Ronni gamel puts an arm around Paul and pulls him hard into his chest Big smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul wanders down the steps toward the pool area, where revelers DANCE. There he watches Dusan dancing with compl abandon, king of the party, sandwiched between Mariette, he kisses open-mouthed, and another woman. Paul is approached by a hippie-ish YOUNG WOMAN, like one meet at a jam-band concert. Paul returns her enigmatic sm She hugs him and whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (above the music) Thanks. So are you. The woman begins dancing. Paul gamely joins in.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m Paul. I live downstairs. She removes a pill from a tiny case and offers it to him.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it? She wiggles her eyebrows suggestively.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to know what it is. Allergies. She places the pill on her extended tongue, sweetening th offer. Paul demurs. She shrugs and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait. Paul turns her around and kisses her, sucking her tongue the pill deeply into his mouth. He assumes there’s more f in store, but she just nods approvingly, strokes his chee dances away.  137 138 139 140 70 INT. DUSAN’S BATHROOM - NIGHT 137 Locking the door, Paul sticks his finger down his throat unsuccessful attempt to induce vomiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circle of people converse in Greek. Paul wanders by, ey wide, smiling, just enjoying the sounds.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I’m going to take off my shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is peaking -- eyes shut, arms overhead, dancing to a rhythm only vaguely related to the music. Dusan wanders b

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I just realized... There’s no reason to be unhappy. I mean, I’m here in Leisureland, but really I’m everywhere. I’m connected to everybody. Everything’s... just the way it’s supposed to be. PAUL'S DRUG-INDUCED POV -- streaked and vibrant. Dusan laughs, looking directly into camera.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, baby! As long as the world is going to shit, let’s make a little money and let’s have a good time. (in Serbian) You’re about to enter whole new world! FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER BLACK
dialogues.text: The sound of a DOORBELL. INT. DUSAN’S LIVING ROOM - DAY CLOSE on Paul passed out on the floor, wedged between a s and a coffee table. The doorbell rings again, startling h awake.  141 71 PAUL’S POV -- Dusan’s hairy legs stagger toward the door, stop short, then approach him.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is that? Who is down there?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s me, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Paul who? Who is Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: From downstairs. You know, Paul. The doorbell again.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Enough with the fucking doorbell! He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (unusual Asian accent) Good morning, Mr. Dusan. We come clean for you. Paul watches the legs of a small cleaning crew enter, interest piqued by one person’s crude PROSTHETIC FOOT. INT. DUSAN’S KITCHEN - DAY Paul shuffles in to find Dusan rooting around.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Fucking hyenas ate everything. I am surprised there is even still water when I turn on the sink. his 141 Paul sits on a stool, and Dusan pours him coffee. From th next room comes the sound of vacuuming. DUSAN (CONT’D) So you had fun last night, yes? You did not know you were so lucky to have exciting neighbor such as me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Never been to a party like that. So many Europeans. Did you know Little Ronni was here? I mean, he’s historic.  72

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: And boring. Good looking dumb Norwegian guy goes around the world having sex with everybody -- women, men, hermaphrodites, dogs, goats, monkeys. He’ll be the first small baby to die of syphilis. But yes, okay, historic. Glancing into the next room, Paul notices that the one-le woman is the one steering the vacuum cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Apparently he still lives in the original colony, you know, over in Norway. I’ve always wanted to see that.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You’ve been there?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: I go once or twice a year. Konrad, too. We make business there. Good business.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Man, that really must be something to see. You can’t even find pictures of it online. Dusan studies Paul.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, my friend. The world is filled with things to see. I don’t know you, Paul, but I like you. I like you very much. And my advice is to get out of your disgusting little fucking apartment and open your eyes. Don’t be so American. Why you even are small if you live like that, like a rat in a cage? And that ugly woman.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Kristen? She’s not ugly.  73

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Only your furniture is more ugly. You are nice guy, Paul, but little bit pathetic guy. You need help -- you know, how to think about life. Last night you dance and you laugh, but inside you cry.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hey, who are you to talk to me like that?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: I am your neighbor, Dusan Mirkovic. And neighbors are friends. And friends tell friends the truth. Okay, maybe sometimes I’m a little bit asshole, but the world needs assholes. Otherwise where would shit come out? 142 INT. DUSAN’S LIVING ROOM - DAY 142 Paul sits with Dusan on the sofa. Dusan smokes a cigar. A some point Konrad wanders by on his way to get coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: When I see big people becoming small, all the new small cities, I see opportunity. I ask myself, Dusan, why the people they become small? To help the environment? Please. They become small to have the things which until now were only for the rich, which, by the way, is the genius of the concept. So I say to my brother Srdjan -- I work with my brother. He’s still big. (low) My wife, too, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (also low) Your wife? How does that work? Dusan gives a quick, furtive “thumbs-up” sign accompanied satisfied nod.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: So I say, why not bring very special items, luxury items, to the small consumer? The things no one else is thinking to bring?  74

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Such as? Dusan holds up his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Cohiba Espléndido. Cuba. The best cigar in the world. How much you pay for this when you are big? (Paul shrugs) Forty-five, fifty dollars. But when you are small, I will sell you this cigar for one dollar.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Still seems like a lot. I mean, a pack of cigarettes is what, twenty cents, most of it tax?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Not if you remember paying fifty dollars for the same cigar. If now you pay only one dollar, you say, I am so happy to be small! And from one Cohiba, we make more than 2000 cigars. Okay, maybe the cigars are not actually made in Cuba. Maybe they are rolled by little Albanians in Podgorica, but who cares? And this is just the one thing. Also perfumes and colognes, wines Bordeaux and Burgundy, brandies and Port and Calvados, caviar, jamdén ibérico, truffles. My brother and I are now in seven small cities. All around the world. Seven.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is all that legal?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Baby, this is Wild West time. Who has time to chase after some fucking Serbian guy five inches tall over a few cigars and some wine? And listen, Paul, anything you want, I can get for you. Anything, anytime. Again Paul notices with concern the one-legged cleaning w as she hobbles upstairs on her way to another room.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (rising) Excuse me a minute.  143 75 INT. DUSAN’S BATHROOM - DAY 143 Paul appears in the doorway and finds the woman rummaging through Dusan’s medicine cabinet and putting some items i her smock.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hello. She spins around, startled. We may recognize her from the news report -- Vietnamese dissident NGOC LAN TRAN. Her green cap reads “Jade Palace Cleansing Service.”

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: These medicine too old. Too old. I clean, take away for you. (holding out a bottle) Na-pro-shien. What this do?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Naproxen. That’s an anti- inflammatory. (off her blank stare) It helps with pain and swelling. She pockets the bottle and picks up another.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: And this one, what this one do?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s... Vicodin. That’s also a pain killer, but it’s, well, you want to be careful with that one.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: (pocketing it) Pain killer? Pain killer good.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You know, this isn’t my apartment, and I know you’re probably in a lot of pain, but I don’t think you should be stealing pills.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I no steal. They too old, no good. Mr. Dusan, he say me okay I take away things. Pills for sick friend. (closing the cabinet) Okay, I finish now. Bathroom clean.  76 She pushes past Paul, and he follows her into -- A144 INT. DUSAN’S SECOND FLOOR HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS A144

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, whatever's wrong with your “friend,” I see you have a really, really bad prosthetic foot. I’m sure it’s causing pain in your right hip and knee, probably both knees. Lower back.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: How you know these things? You doctor?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m an occupational therapist. Wait a second. I know you. You’re that -- Oh, my God, you’re that woman from a couple years ago, the dissident. From Thailand or someplace. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Tran Ngoc Lan. Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, right, I remember you lost your leg below the knee. That’s you? Wow. (to Dusan and Konrad downstairs) Hey, Dusan, do you know who this is?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, the famous Ngoc Lan Tran. Dramatic escape from Vietnamese prison and almost died so that now she can clean my house. America, big land of opportunity! Dusan and Konrad share a big laugh. 144 INT. DUSAN’S DINING ROOM - DAY 144 Ngoc Lan sits in a chair while Paul cups a kneecap and manipulates the foreleg, then repeats the process with th other leg. Dusan and Konrad watch, as do, from afar, the of the cleaning crew. Ngoc Lan submits to the exam but seems more interested in himself than in what he’s saying.  77

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m going to push down and you try to push up. Mm-hm. You’ve got some pretty severe asymmetrical muscle compensation.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Paul, you are full of surprises. You can do this but you work shit job answering phones?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: When I moved here, I didn’t think I’d be working, so I let my license expire. And to get a license now in a different state... it’s a boring story.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: (to the other cleaners) Hey, you no look me! You work now. Trabajo! Trabajo! As they scatter, Paul places Ngoc Lan's hand on her own k and moves her foreleg up and down.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You feel that crunching? That’s arthritis. It’s already pretty bad. (releasing it) I hate to say it, but if you don’t take care of it, pretty soon you’re going to need a new knee. And that’s just for starters. Maybe a new hip too. You should see a specialist as soon as you can and get a whole new foot. Ngoc Lan says nothing. Does she understand?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the meantime, I could make a few adjustments to your existing prosthetic and give you some pointers on how to walk better. I hate to see you suffer needlessly after all you've been through.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Okay, I finish work you come with me.  145 146 78

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Great. I’11 just grab some tools and we can do it right here.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: No. I say you before my friend sick, need pills. You come with me my house help her. You help her. This situation is getting confusing and weird.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I guess I wasn’t clear. See, I can help you with this, but I’m not a doctor. Your friend, whatever's wrong with her, should go to a clinic or hospital.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Clinic no good! I take her clinic wait too long time. Stupid doctor say no help for her, no do nothing. He no good stupid doctor in big world, now he small. You come with me! You come with me now! Paul looks to Dusan for help, but Dusan just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, now cleaned up, rides with Ngoc Lan in a crowded ca The other PASSENGERS, many in work uniforms, are mostly Latino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan and Paul exit the station amid a flow of humanit

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You live near here?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Still far.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe we should grab a car.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: No car. This way. Ngoc Lan limps past him, pointing toward a shuttle stop w three BUSES are taking on passengers.  147 148 79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus drives away from central Leisureland and enters a modest section of town -- smallish houses, LATINO CHILDRE playing in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan and Paul have found a seat, but the aisle is pac Buoyant RANCHERA MUSIC on the speakers contrasts with the weary faces of the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind my asking, you were so famous a couple years ago. Everybody was talking about you. I would've thought you’d be writing books and making speeches. I mean, how’d you wind up cleaning houses?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Need money for live. After TV box I stay hospital so long time, almost die. Then three host family, but too much problems. Leisureland peoples too selfish. Better I live only me, work job make money.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But after all you've been through, I would have thought for sure Tony Dale would have been happy to --

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Don’t say me Tony Dale! (mocking) Tony Dale. Tony Dale. (a sudden tirade) Everybody say Tony Dale so nice guy, help people. I say he bad man, make Leisureland people selfish. I say you why Tony Dale still big? Be careful you ask him this. He no like this question. I ask him, he say me, “You go back Vietnam TV box, you talk like this.” He say me, “I save your life my hospital, make you better, now why you make bad PR for me.” He say me ungrateful. He say me selfish. He say me female dog! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Female dog okay Vietnamese, but female dog English very bad name call woman. Tony Dale. Paul nods politely at the outburst. Glancing outside, he notes that the bus is now passing through -- EXT. NO MAN’S LAND - DAY An area of undeveloped lots and fields. One entire square block has been removed, the resulting h surrounded by safety barriers. NORMAL-SIZED MEN in hard h work down below, only their heads visible above ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul now cranes his neck to look through the front windsh and discovers that the bus is headed directly toward THE encircling Leisureland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus disappears into the wall’s shadow and heads towar TUNNEL in the wall. Graffiti around the entrance has made look like the pupil of a giant eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus motors through the darkness of the tunnel, finall emerging into the light. EXT. WORKERS’ CITY - DAY The bus comes to a stop, and Paul follows Ngoc Lan off. This is essentially a BORDER TOWN. Here the protective overhead netting hangs much lower and is poorly maintaine Paul notices the sagging weight of a BIRD CARCASS. As Ngoc Lan leads him, he continues to take in a world he no idea existed. Most imposing is the sight of --

dialogues.speaker: NORMAL-SIZED TRAILERS
dialogues.text: of the sort used for portable classrooms or construction offices. Here they’ve been re-purposed into apartment buildings, with rows of tiny windows and crisscrossed boo wiring. 149 150 151 152 153  154 155 156 81 Ngoc Lan leads Paul up the entrance ramp to one particula trailer named ALONDRA, dodging Spanish-speaking CHILDREN tobogganing past on normal-size bottle caps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepping inside, Paul pauses to absorb the extraordinary interior view. Like inside an Embassy Suites or a high- security prison, walkways on every floor surround an ATRI On the ground floor, RESIDENTS watch a 26” television, wh in this context rises three stories tall. The sound of a garish Spanish-language program echoes throughout. Ngoc Lan heads toward a staircase and begins to climb, he speed impressive.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (catching up) Can I ask how high we’re going?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Seven floor.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Isn’t there an elevator?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Elevator broken. You walk with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul arrives out of breath, but Ngoc Lan seems fine. As they proceed down the walkway, Paul and Ngoc Lan navig around chatting NEIGHBORS and CHILDREN at play. Murals an graffiti adorn the walls, and the rickety railings are reinforced with dental floss. INT. NGOC LAN’S APARTMENT - DAY 156 Ngoc Lan and Paul enter this tiny apartment decorated wit improvised furnishings -- a table made from a spray can l chairs carved out of champagne corks, curtains fashioned old handkerchiefs. Most striking are the images of BUTTERFLIES cut from norm size magazines used to cover the walls. Ngoc Lan pulls back a curtain to reveal GLADYS, a barely conscious Salvadoran woman lying on a piece of foam.  82

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: This lady Gladys. Gladys my friend. She very sick. (loudly) Gladys, how you feel? éCdémo estaé? éCémo esta? I bring food for you. I bring doctor. This man doctor. Hombre médico. Médico. Gladys offers Paul a weak, hopeful smile. NGOC LAN (CONT’D) This lady Gladys alone, no have nobody. Husband die Mexico when they make small. Stupid people forget take out gold from teeth, head explode.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Husband head explode. Head explode. From teeth. She come here alone, no money. I meet her she work maid first host family, rich Leisureland people. Now she sick, no more work. (pointing) Okay you take care for her. As Ngoc Lan goes to fill a pail from a crude faucet, Paul a wave of panic and pulls her aside.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can’t do anything for her. That woman is really sick. She looks like she might die.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Oh yes she die soon. Cancer. Cancer all over stomach. I be with her die. Most bad thing die alone. Ngoc Lan kneels at Gladys’s side and gives her water. NGOC LAN (CONT’D) (loud whisper) Come on, be like doctor. Make her feel good. (to Gladys) Hombre médico. Paul draws a deep breath and assumes the role he’s been a to play, squatting down and dredging up his medical Spani  83

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hola, senfora. éDdénde le duele?

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Ay, doctor, me duele todo, todo. Ya no me queda mucho tiempo en esta vida. Ngoc Lan reaches into her sack and begins placing bottle bottle of drugs onto a table.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Which pill good for her? How much she take?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: But you know things. One, two, five, what? Which one most strong?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That one. Percocet.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: (opening it) Yes, Percocet. Very good for pain.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Try two.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Two? This lady very sick. Pills old. Give four. Paul helps her administer the pills.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: These are for the pain.

dialogues.speaker: GLADYS
dialogues.text: Gracias, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You rest now. Gladys closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you been moving her around? You know, like every few hours? You don’t want her to get bed sores.  157 84 Ngoc Lan shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Let’s move her. He instructs Ngoc Lan with gestures, and they begin to ro Gladys onto her side.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: See? You know things. LATER -- Gladys now lies in a narcotized state. 157 NGOC LAN (CONT’D) Thank you Mr. Dusan friend. You help Gladys good.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now let’s make those adjustments for you. (reaching for his tools) I’1l just need you to remove your foot.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Not now. I very tired. You go away. I stay with Gladys. You go away now. With no further ceremony, Ngoc Lan goes and busies hersel the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well. Some other time, I guess. I just don’t know when I’m going to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: You come Thursday, okay? Thursday morning you fix leg. You come ten o'clock. At a loss, Paul opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My name’s Paul, by the way. Paul Safranek. Ngoc Lan glances up and gives a little nod. Paul takes a look at this strange creature, then leaves.  158 159 85

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark now. As Paul exits the building, his attention drawn by whooping and shouting. A jubilant GROUP OF MEN have just rolled up a normal-size of TECATE BEER. On the count of “Uno, dos, tres,” they ho it up and begin to spin it and shake it. Finally, they drop it on the ground, and with practiced e one of them punctures the can with a screwdriver, sending geyser of beer high into the air. They roll the can this way and that to guide the spray in their mouths. Others laugh as they are hosed down with be Paul watches, wistful at the spectacle of this simple pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul squints at his monitor, painfully aware of the senselessness of his job.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Let’s see. Extra Large is still available in glacier, pebble, tulip, cayenne, moss and aubergine.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Cayenne, is that like red?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: More of a brownish red. Like brick.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I don’t like brick. Do you think moss is pretty?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You know, I don’t know, lady. Could you please just pick a color?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Don’t be short with me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Oooh, I see. You’re small. You’re one of those disgusting little small people.  86

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s right. And you’re extra large. Paul tosses his headset on his desk and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying a small canvas bag, Paul knocks on Ngoc Lan’s do Soon Ngoc Lan opens it and invites Paul in. INT. NGOC LAN’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS 161 Upon entering Paul notices that Gladys is gone.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where’s Gladys?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: She die.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I think maybe I give her too much pills. Anyway, she die very happy smiling. Appalled, Paul musters a strained smile. Ngoc Lan sits an loosens her leg. NGOC LAN (CONT’D) Okay, you fix my foot quick. You do quick. One hour. Must clean house soon.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can’t exactly fix it, but I can make a few adjustments, and I can give you some pointers on how to walk better. It’s a process. And I think I found the right orthopedist for you. Ngoc Lan slides the prosthesis off and hands it over. LATER -- Paul works on the crudely constructed foot, push and pulling on the hinges and springs. Now on CRUTCHES, N Lan manages to bring him a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. Very nice.  87

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: You finish soon okay? I very busy. Go work soon.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m getting there. Ngoc Lan sits.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess you like butterflies. (pointing at the walls) Butterflies.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Yes I like very much. When I little girl my father she take with my sister see butterfly. Near my village they come live trees. You know, fly from cold place to hot place every year. Live trees near village then go away come back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, migrating butterflies. Sounds beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Yes so many butterfly in tree very beautiful. I no forget. So many color.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How do you say butterfly in Vietnamese?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Con bu’6’m.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Kon booyem.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: (amused) Con bu’6’m.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You must miss your village.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: No more village. Government make people go away put water all over village, all over everywhere. Too much water.  88

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Too much water?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Big water make electricity.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A dam.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Yes, dam. They make dam. Many villages no more. This why I go prison. Me my sister make big protest.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Huh. What happened to your sister?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: She die prison. Too much cold. Chest fill up bad. She die. A solemn moment passes. Then Paul applies extra force to stubborn coupling and -- KKRCH! -- the joint pops apart a the entire prosthetic collapses in his hands. NGOC LAN (CONT’D) What happen? Paul tries awkwardly to shield the broken foot from view.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing, I think I just -- A spring and a bolt or two drop noisily onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul carries Ngoc Lan piggy-back down the stairs. She clutches her crutches.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: You stupid man! You say help me. This no help! You break my foot!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You’re just lucky it didn’t fail while you were walking down these stairs. You could’ve broken your neck!  89

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Many people depend for me! I okay before, walk around good. Even I forget I have no foot. Now you come, make my life more harder!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You needed a new foot anyway. We're going to get you a good one. Is that so hard to understand? Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: No say Jesus bad way!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Now I’m supposed to watch my language? What am I, twelve? You’re worse than my mother.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for your mother! I sure she suffer too much for your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a vacuum cleaner. WIDE -- Paul is the one guiding it, now wearing a “Jade P Cleansing Service” cap. Ngoc Lan sits nearby.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: No do so fast! Vacuum cleaner need time same direction clean good. He shoots her a resentful glance, then notices other CREW MEMBERS whispering to each other and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul cleans the stove. Ngoc Lan sits on a chair helping t LADY OF THE HOUSE go through the refrigerator as they pul leftovers and stack them in a box.

dialogues.speaker: LADY OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: And you can take this -- that’s turkey casserole from a couple days ago. These avocados are a bit soft, but --  90

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, yes. I take all these.

dialogues.speaker: LADY OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: (a Tupperware container) I think this one’s leftover pasta. It might be a little too old. Ngoc Lan peels open the lid and peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: In prison we die for such food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan waits in a car outside this downsized version of familiar franchise. Accompanied by the manager ROGER, Paul exits the front do and heads toward the car. Both carry take-out food containers. Paul opens the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (to Ngoc Lan) Not too many leftover entrées today, but I threw in lots of baked potato soup.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Finally got yourself a helper, huh, Ngoc Lan?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: This Paul. He break my foot.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: How’d you manage that, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: He stupid.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Long story. We’re sorting it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan threads her way on crutches through TV VIEWERS i atrium. Some call out warm greetings. Paul follows with trays of left-over food.  91 They reach SENOR CARDENAS, a frail old man dozing ina wheelchair. Ngoc Lan gives him a gentle nudge.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Hola, Senor Cardenas. éHambre?

dialogues.speaker: SENOR CARDENAS
dialogues.text: Ay, si, chinita. Gracias. She places food from Paul’s stack on the old man’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: SENOR CARDENAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God will repay you.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: How’s your lung? How’s your lung?

dialogues.speaker: SENOR CARDENAS
dialogues.text: A little better today, gracias. Ngoc Lan nods approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Okay over here next. This way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOTHER lifts her nine-year-old SON’s shirt to reveal re circles on his chest and back. The woman’s HUSBAND looks Ngoc Lan looks to Paul for a verdict.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ouch. Okay. That looks painful. Mucho dolor, verdad?

dialogues.speaker: SON
dialogues.text: Si.
