dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I give him baths and scrub him and put herbs, but nothing helps.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I bet that’s ringworm. I don’t know how to say that in Spanish. (thinking) Ringworm’s a fungus, so... No bafo. No bano. No agua. Seco. Seco. (to Ngoc Lan) Maybe I can find something at the drugstore and bring it for him tomorrow.  170 171 172 92

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Yes, you bring. (to the woman) Manana medicina.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Manana medicina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan and Paul stand at an open door, distributing the of the food to unseen recipients.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s it, right? Ready to go home?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Now we go church pray Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARISHIONERS sing a hymn. Some shake tambourines. Trying be a good sport, Paul stands next to Ngoc Lan, but he has never been more out of his element.

dialogues.speaker: HYMN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jesucristo es el Sefor. Jesucristo es el Sefior... LATER -- The Spanish-speaking MINISTER shouts into a 171 microphone, his words distorted by a cheap amp. The faith sway back and forth, eyes closed, one hand raised, Ngoc L among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul carries Ngoc Lan piggy-back upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: You come back tomorrow morning pick me up. Eight o’clock.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. I'’11 be there. Paul loses his balance for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Careful!  173 174 93

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I got you. Stop shifting around!

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. DUSAN’S HALLWAY - DAY 173 CLOSE on a door and the sound of a familiar doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, okay! I’m coming! The door is opened by an unshaven, hungover Dusan, who lo into camera and dissolves into laughter. REVERSE ANGLE -- It’s Ngoc Lan and her cleaning crew, amo them a fully uniformed and humiliated Paul.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Dusan. We come clean for you. INT. DUSAN’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS 174 As the crew enter and disperse to clean up the post-party mess, we see that Ngoc Lan now sports a PEG LEG. Dusan puts his arm around Paul’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Answering phones was not dignified enough for you, I see. Now you progress to cleaning toilets. I love you, Paul. I really love you. You are such a funny guy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Like I said, Paul, you are too much nice guy and little bit pathetic guy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, I broke her damn foot! What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: This is absolutely fantastic. (yelling) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Konrad, Konrad! You must come see something! This is so fucking funny!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s just until she gets a new foot.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: And how long will that be?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The doctor said a month, maybe six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: That’s an eternity.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Meantime she’s stuck with a peg leg, which is almost worse than nothing at all. She’s waddling around like a goddamned pirate!

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Paul! No talk with Mr. Dusan! You go upstairs with Verdénica! Paul is trained to obey but hesitates under Dusan’s gaze. NGOC LAN (CONT’D) Paul!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I heard you! As Paul trots off, Dusan doubles over.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, Paul. Dusan will save you. INT. DUSAN’S KITCHEN - DAY 175 Ngoc Lan sorts through leftovers, muttering to herself.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: This good... I take this... (smelling a box) Ooh, this throw away... This, I don’t know what this is. Dusan and Konrad enter behind her.  95

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, please, Miss Tran, take everything. Mr. Konrad and I are leaving day after tomorrow and don’t know when we will be back.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Okay good. Thank you. Dusan motions for Paul to join them. NGOC LAN (CONT’D) Paul, Mr. Dusan say I take food. You go find big box.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, in a minute. First there’s something very important to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: (turning around) Yes? INT. DUSAN’S KITCHEN TABLE - DAY 176 The four have gathered for a talk around the table.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Listen, here is the situation. I don’t know exactly what, but something big -- very big -- is happening at the original small colony. You know, the one in Norway. They want me to go there right away with a very important delivery. Too complicated to explain. Top secret and very urgent. Most important they are offering us very big money.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: Very big.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: This means we need extra help to do this quickly and make them happy. And I’m sorry to say, we need the same excellent helper who is currently helping you. (pointing at Paul) Him. The room falls silent as Ngoc Lan lets this sink in.  96

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, Ngoc Lan, I have to go to Norway with these guys.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: So... you say... Paul go with you Norway?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Yes, that is the situation. Emergency situation.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: And deeply humanitarian. Instead of arguing, Ngoc Lan remains subdued.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Paul, you want go Mr. Dusan Norway?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s what I just said. I mean, look, Ngoc Lan, I’1l still be able to help one-hundred-percent when I get home and when you get your new foot, and --

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: You leave Wednesday?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: And how long you go? Paul looks to the men for help.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: At least ten days. Maybe more. Ngoc Lan performs mental calculations, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Yes, okay, Norway. I go Norway too.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: No, no, no, not you. Only Paul.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I go Norway too. Paul, you help me during trip.  177 97

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: But you’re very busy here with humanitarian activities of your own. And your cleaning business.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Ver6nica and other ladies know every place. They do for me, I pay them good. No problem I go. (cheery now) Norway colony peoples invite me so many time but I never go. Feel so, so guilty. They so nice peoples.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: What? Who invited you?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: When I hospital so long time after TV box, people all over world send me happy card, flower, candy, make me feel good. So many letter. One letter very special I never forget. From Jorgen Asbjornsen. Tears well up in her eyes. The men exchange panicked look NGOC LAN (CONT’D) Dr. Asbj@rnsen she write me say he feel so, so bad I suffer for his fault. He say he painful, he never think make small so bad for people. Dr. Asbjornsen letter make me feel so better. I write letter too, say now first time I proud be small. So good man. He say me make trip go Norway any day. But I too busy, always too busy. Now Jesus give me beautiful gift, go Norway. Thank you Mr. Dusan, thank you Mr. Konrad. Yes, yes, I go Norway. So happy. (crying) Thank you special time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunning views of the lush valley of an ocean inlet. Radi colors reflect off high, verdant cliffs. Konrad’s yacht cruises up the fjord towing a barge loaded cargo, including huge, normal-sized bottles of VODKA.  178 179 180 98 EXT. KONRAD’S YACHT - DAY 178 Paul stands at the prow, the wind in his hair, Ngoc Lan b him. Paul looks up at the wheel house, where Konrad is at the chatting with Dusan. Then he looks down at Ngoc Lan’s PEG LEG. It’s all so odd, so unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, we see Paul, Ngoc Lan, Dusan and Konrad dining together, enjoying the splendid view. Dusan clowns the delight of the others, and Ngoc Lan seems unusually relaxed and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul helps Ngoc Lan down the steps to the sleeping area, she opens the door to her cabin.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Good night, Paul. I’m sure you have very much work to do with Dusan Konrad. Very important job only you can do.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Um, yeah. Well --

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I know you no like cleaning. I too big boss, you try run away from me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, no. That’s not --

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: No good lie me. Jesus my friend. He always say me truth. Paul squints at her. Is she for real? Then Ngoc Lan laugh an endearing honk.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you want help with your leg?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I take care myself. Good night, Paul.  181 182 99

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good night. Sleep well. Paul watches her go, surprised by sudden pangs of longing INT. PAUL’S CABIN - NIGHT 181 Paul awakens when the engine suddenly cuts, and the boat to a stop. Voices and footsteps follow. Paul rises to peer out his tiny porthole. In the moonligh makes out a SKIFF pulling alongside the yacht and TWO NEW PASSENGERS helped off the skiff and onto the yacht. EXT. KONRAD’S YACHT - DAY 182 An unshaven Paul emerges onto the deck and is about to he the wheelhouse when he notices -- NGOC LAN and an ELDERLY MAN AND WOMAN seated on the rear deck, conversing. The woman leans forw to clasp one of Ngoc Lan's hands in empathy and consolati Paul makes his way astern.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Look, Paul. This Jorgen Asbjornsen. And her wife. Upon meeting the Asbjornsens again, we see that the years stress have not been kind.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. Jorgen Asbjornsen. Hello. This is such an honor.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: See, Paul? Jesus smile for me. (to the Asbjornsens) I say Paul I want visit Norway only meet you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: I’m Anne-Helene. Please, sit. Join us. We’re watching the world go by.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: You’ve no idea how terribly grief- stricken we were by Miss Tran’s case.  100

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: Yes. Jorgen has lost so much sleep over all the abuses. (to Ngoc Lan) It’s such a pleasure to meet you at last. I just can’t tell you. A few moments of quiet as all take in the surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: It’s humbling, no? Nature is such a patient sculptor -- grinding a tiny bit each day slowly, slowly for thousands of years to make such a supremely beautiful thing. (overcome with sadness) What a waste. What a dreadful waste. Dr. Asbj@rnsen rises and shuffles away, muttering to hims in Norwegian.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: You’ll have to excuse Jorgen. These past few days have been especially hard. Such a big decision to make. And so quickly. Normally when we visit the Colony, we like to take the train and spend a few days in Narvik. But then the news came and, well, here we are, suddenly imposing on you. We scarcely had time to pack.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but what news?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: Why, the methane release. In Antarctica. You must know about the methane.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sure... But that’s not new, right? I mean --

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: New or old, it’s the end. The end of everything. (vising) I’m sorry, I should check on Jorgen.  101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All aboard have gathered for dinner around a table and li intently to the great man in their midst.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: The Earth has already seen five major extinctions, and now there will be another. I didn’t want to believe it, none of us did. But there we were in Helsinki, big and small -- climatologists, biologists, physicists, demographers, immunologists, 26 Nobel Prize winners among us. We built all the models, did all the math, and the conclusion was consistent. Homo Sapiens will soon vanish from the Earth. The only question is when. Some say 500 years. Some say sixty. Now with the terrible spike in methane release, it’s out of our grasp. Regardless how the end will come -- unbreathable air, impotable water, incurable disease, environmental catastrophe, nuclear winter, likely a combination of them all -- relatively soon the Earth will indeed purge itself of human life, and God knows how many other species. It is now an actuarial certainty. His mind reeling, Paul looks at Ngoc Lan. She has been listening quietly, but tears flow down her face. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) (pouring himself a drink) Not a very successful species, these Homo Sapiens, even with such great intelligence. Barely 200 thousand years. Alligator has survived 200 million years with a brain the size of a walnut.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you really mean extinction? What about downsizing?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, too little too late. Only 3% of the world has miniaturized. There simply isn’t enough time. Yes, extinction is exactly the correct word.  184 185 102

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul and Ngoc Lan lean against the railing, soothed by th stars and the wind.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: People have been predicting the end of the world for thousands of years, and now it’s really happening. I guess somebody had to be right someday.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: So sad. Very sad. They gaze at the moonlit landscape. The moment is ripe fo love. Ngoc Lan looks at Paul, hoping he’1ll sense her nee but he seems oblivious, and she starts to walk away. NGOC LAN (CONT’D) Sleep now. Good night, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Good night, Ngoc Lan. Surprised by her abrupt departure, Paul watches her go. T she pauses, emitting a barely audible grunt of pain.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I fine.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe I should take a look.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Yes. You look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan lies on the bed with one pant leg rolled up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yeah, that peg’s making the socket chafe a little. Paul squeezes lotion into his palm and begins to massage tender skin of Ngoc Lan’s stump.  186 187 103

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, if someone had told me five years ago that one day I’d be four inches tall, divorced, helping a famous Vietnamese dissident get a new foot, and cruising up a fjord in Norway discussing the end of the world with Jorgen Asbjernsen, I would have said he was crazy. Paul notices she hasn’t been listening. Her eyes are clos and her head is tipped back. She moans slightly. Paul stops massaging. Ngoc Lan opens her eyes just enough give him a look, then closes them again. Summoning his courage, he lies down next to her and plants his lips on She’s stiff and unresponsive, so he stops.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I thought... Jesus, I’m such an idiot. Ngoc Lan opens her eyes and gives Paul a look at once fie and vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: No. Please. I want. Paul draws a deep breath, eases his way close again and g her a few gentle kisses. Ever so slowly, she reciprocates FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: A STRANGE SOUND
dialogues.text: EXT. KONRAD’S YACHT - MORNING Zipping up parkas as they emerge onto the deck, Ngoc Lan Paul discover a different landscape. The walls of the fjo are narrower, the terrain even lusher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Paul and Ngoc Lan enter, Konrad and Dusan exchange a knowing look. There are no secrets on a boat.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What’s that sound?  188 189 190 191 192 104

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: A greeting. Konrad blasts the foghorn in response. When Ngoc Lan look away, Dusan gives Paul a wink and makes a crude gesture. responds with a glare that says, “Cool it.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny BEARDED MAN in rustic clothing stands on a cliff blowing into a lacquered SNAIL SHELL. OOOEEEEOOOOOO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motoring into a bay, the boat approaches a loading dock. few downsized fishing boats are moored in the harbor, the prows carved into dragon heads as an homage to Viking heritage. No dwellings are in sight -- just the dock, two cargo cra and a road leading away from port. HORSE-DRAWN CARTS with DRIVERS await the yacht’s arrival. EXT. KONRAD’S YACHT - DAY 190 Dusan stands with Paul and Ngoc Lan at the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harnessed horses pull a wooden cart up a steep series of switchbacks. Paul, Ngoc Lan, Dusan and the Asbjornsens ri together in back. In the distance below, cranes unload th yacht’s cargo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan is staggered by the immediacy and immensity of n from a small perspective -- trees tall as mountains, leav broad as sails. Paul shares the feeling but even more delights in watching Ngoc Lan.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: I think never in my life I will see some place so beautiful again.  193 194 105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cart crests a hill and pauses to enjoy the remarkable view. A lush valley cradles a village surrounded by tiere fields. Near the village are larger, more modern building

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: All this land -- everything you see -- belonged for centuries to the Edvardsen family. It was Nellie Edvardsen’s granddaughter Solveig who arranged for us to use this place for our settlement.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: Solveig will remind you of this many times.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: Jorgen.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: (with distaste) Solveig.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So that’s it. The colony. And that’s the original dome. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: We use it now as a social hall and fitness center, but yes, this is where we started.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: It was a wonderful time. Remember, Jorgen?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: (wistful) I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cart passes through a gate and into the settlement, a marriage between a traditional Scandinavian village and a modern eco-commune. The residents’ appearance suggests a life of communal val and harmony with nature -- long hair, sandals, beards, ru cheeks, rustic garments. ALL RACES are represented.  195 106 There’s a sense of urgency among the villagers as they bu about, but they’re not too busy to cheer the Asbjornsens they pass. The couple respond humbly with smiles and wave

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Papa Jorgen! Mama Anne-Helene!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cart stops near a large, weathered SHED built into th side of a hill. A small welcoming party of SCIENTISTS and ENGINEERS greet the new arrivals.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jorgen, Anne-Helene! Oh, thank God you’ve arrived! Why didn’t anyone tell me? All turn to see SOLVEIG EDVARDSEN running toward them. A sized Norwegian woman in her 60s, she’s hiking up the hem her long, flowing garments to avoid the mud.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: (smiling stiffly) Solveig. Solveig makes a big show of embracing the Asbjernsens, dr them into her ample bosom.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: I love you. I love you both so much. Ever since the decision, I didn’t feel right without you here. And you know how I am when I worry. I can’t eat. I can’t sleep. Ask anyone here, they’1l tell you. My stomach has been so upset, like I want to throw up all the time, but can’t. And I’ve had an awful headache that just won’t go away. I know you know about my headaches. I love you so much. Thank God you’re here -- I feel so much better now, like a big release. A FELLOW SCIENTIST comes to the rescue.

dialogues.speaker: FELLOW SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: Sorry to interrupt, Jorgen, but we need your advice immediately.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Excuse us, Solveig.  Unplugged the other 107

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: Of course, darling. You’ve got important things to do. I love you. You’re a genius.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: (heading away too) You look wonderful, Solveig.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: Really? I do? You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-HELENE
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: (grateful) Oh, honey. from the attention she craves, Solveig latches onto new arrivals. SOLVEIG (CONT’D) Dusan, Dusan, dear Dusan. Bless you for coming so quickly. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: (kissing her cheeks) Solveig, my darling, I am always happy to help -- in difficult times, in easy times, in happy times. Is always a pleasure to visit you and your lovely village.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: It is lovely, isn’t it? I can’t bear to think I won’t see it again. (to Paul and Ngoc Lan) You know, I’m the one who made this colony possible in the first place. I’ve been coming since I was just a baby. Papa used to fly us here every summer in his float plane. I remember one time -- (to Paul) Wait. I know you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: (gripping his arm) I’m sure of it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were in my dream last night. I was a little girl, and I was afraid and lonely, but there you were, walking beside me.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Are you sure it was me? Because we've never --

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: You were a horse or a pony -- something very strong -- and I instantly felt better. Then I mounted you and rode you through a dangerous forest. And here you are. Right before we leave. Another miracle. You are coming with us, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: (jumping in) Solveig, darling, listen, we love you, but my friends and I are just here for the delivery, and then we must go home.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: That’s really so sad. We’d love it if you’d join us.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, did you say you’re leaving?

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: Oh. Yes. All of us. Didn’t anyone tell you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Solveig points at the shed -- isn’t it obvious?

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: In there. Would you like to see? (leading them, to Dusan) You did remember my hand cream, didn’t you? I couldn’t survive without it.  196

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 109 196 Solveig escorts the group inside. To Paul and Ngoc Lan's surprise, they find that the rustic shelter conceals the entrance to -- A LARGE TUNNEL, disappearing into the mountain like a min shaft.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Where it go?

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: To China! (giggling) — ; I’m sorry, forgive me. Sometimes I’m so silly. No, to the vault.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The vault?

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. We’ve been working on it almost since the very beginning. Actually, not many people know this, but it was my idea

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Of course it was. You’re always thinking ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: When Jorgen made his big discovery, I said, look, Jorgen, you’re a genius, and downsizing is a genius idea. No one’s questioning that. No one. But what if people don’t accept it? What if it doesn’t catch on in time? Look at me -- you know, it took me years before I did it. I had to sell my antiques and find homes for my cats. They’re very old and one of them is diabetic, needs two shots every day. It was a complete nightmare. Anyway, this is what they came up with. On my suggestion. Solveig leads Ngoc Lan and Paul toward TORVALD, seated at a control panel. SOLVEIG (CONT’D) Torvald, be a sweetheart and give our friends a little tour. an engineer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tunnel leads to a vault 1.6 kilometers inside the Earth’s lithosphere and encased in a double layer of Inconel 625. Torvald points at an array of MONITORS displaying high-an views of streets, homes, farms and pastures. TORVALD (CONT’D) In addition to maintaining a broad spectrum of biodiversity, the vault is equipped with fields for growing foods, forests for lumber, livestock for animal husbandry. The residential areas are spacious and easily expandable to provide for future generations.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Wait, that’s not underground.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: Of course it is! Our new size makes it possible. Otherwise we never could have dreamed of preserving so much of the world in a single safe place.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This is brilliant. (to Ngoc Lan) Isn’t this brilliant? Like Noah’s Ark.

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: That’s exactly what I told Jorgen. It’s Noah’s Ark!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What kind of power are you using, nuclear?

dialogues.speaker: TORVALD
dialogues.text: No, no, 100% geothermal. Interoperable organic systems manage production of artificial sunlight, oxygen, CO2 elimination, water purification, and so forth. As Paul soaks everything up, Ngoc Lan takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So how long will you stay down there?  197

dialogues.speaker: SOLVEIG
dialogues.text: What is it, Torvald? Eight thousand years?

dialogues.speaker: TORVALD
dialogues.text: (lips pursed) Something like that. Until the surface environment stabilizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the villagers -- perhaps 250 -- dine together at long wooden tables. Tonight the atmosphere is electric. Paul and Ngoc Lan sit near the Asbjornsens and other SCIENTISTS who, between chews, dispassionately explain th project at hand. Konrad and Dusan sit nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ONE SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: You know, it’s not unprecedented what we are doing. Less than a hundred thousand years ago humans experienced a near-extinction. Maybe 2,000 survived. And from that handful came all the billions of people you see today.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: Rebooting the species. Nothing new. Glasses clink. Dr. Asbjornsen rises. Never a comfortable public speaker, he scans the faces turned his way.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: My friends. Many years ago, when we discovered cellular miniaturization, the world which had seemed so doomed felt suddenly so full of possibilities. We knew we had found the portal to the next stage of man’s evolution. So until very recently, I maintained hope that the contingency plan we embark upon tomorrow could remain simply that -- a plan. He pauses, reigning in his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: But history has spoken, and this is our final dinner in the place we’ve called home for so many years. And here, on this beautiful little island (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: (noticing Solveig’s look) -- this island which Solveig Edvardsen had the vision and generosity to provide us... Solveig nods proudly. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) ...the very survival of mankind rests in our hands. Yes, we are sad to leave, and terribly sad for the reasons why, but man is too beautiful, too improbable a life form to be allowed to disappear forever from the cosmos. (Norwegian) It is no shame to look into the warm spring sun and regret a lost limb. The Norwegians present nod and murmur in agreement. Someo uses the moment to hand Asbjornsen a note. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) Ah, yes. The kitchen staff wishes to remind everyone that after you scrape your plates, you should place them in the stacking carts, not the dish washing belts. (clearing his throat) Now then, I would like to ask the surviving members of the original colony to stand. Twenty people solemnly rise. Most are in their fifties or older, but among them we recognize one handsome young man DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) Look at him -- Little Ronni, how he’s grown. As Ronni smiles, we note a herpes sore on his upper lip. DR. ASBJ®RNSEN (CONT’D) (addressing the originals) I ask you again as I asked you so many years ago. Generations to come - - perhaps all of humanity -- will thank you for your bravery and commitment. But you must ask yourself whether you are truly ready to enter a new world. For there will be no turning back. Are you ready?  113

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RONNI
dialogues.text: I am ready!

dialogues.speaker: ORIGINAL COLONY MEMBERS
dialogues.text: Yes! I am ready! Yes! Tears and embraces throughout the room.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ASBJ
dialogues.text: Is everyone ready? Shouts of “I am ready!” coalesce into an ebullient group of “We are ready.” Konrad, Ngoc Lan and Dusan are moved to witness these momentous proceedings, but Paul’s reaction is even more profound. Something deep inside him is awakening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Residents throw furniture into a BONFIRE. Drunken men sin Viking songs. A hypnotic drum beat inspires dancing.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Konrad, what do you think? Is the end of civilization really coming so soon?

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: Look here. My uncle used to say he was born during the Austro-Hungarian Empire, then outlived both the Third Reich and Communism, all three of which were supposed to last forever. In the 1930s they discovered a pyramid in Egypt -- a pyramid! -- when a camel stubbed its toe. How does one lose a pyramid? Or look up at the sky. So many of those bright, bright stars went dark before humans even existed -- we just don’t know it yet. All things come to an end. Why shouldn’t we? But look at the positive side -- if our world really is coming to an end, it’s fascinating to be watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul sits alone, deep in thought, looking down at the tun entrance.  114 The shed has been dismantled, and work lights illuminate parade of carts heading inside loaded with supplies. Ngoc Lan approaches, struggling up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Where you go? I look many place for you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’ve been here.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: (sitting) I talk with Dusan, he say fat lady pay, he ready go back. I happy for that. Too long time away from Sefior Cardenas and Mrs. Lopez. I worry too much for them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan, you can’t just be worried about a few little people thousands of miles away. You have to look at the big picture.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Why you say like this?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Because Mr. Cardenas, Mrs. Ldpez, they don’t stand a chance, none of us do! (gesturing) All of this -- it’s over. Can’t you see what’s going on? This is a defining moment in human history. More than that -- in the history of the universe. And for some reason you and I are here.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: You want go with them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And I want you to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: You crazy man! Always I know you stupid. Now I see you crazy too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I crazy? You heard them. This is the only chance for the survival of our species -- that’s huge! You want to help people? These are the people you should be helping. The future of humanity is down that hole!

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Who you help down there? People here needs help, not down stupid hole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ngoc Lan pulls Paul by the hand toward Dusan and Konrad, now quite drunk.

dialogues.speaker: NGOC LAN
dialogues.text: Dusan, Konrad, talk to crazy Paul. He say he want go down hole, me go with him.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Paul, Paul, Paul, Paul... Why would you do such a silly thing?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Because you will live the rest of your life in a hole in the ground. Like a worm.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: These people are saving the human race, and I want to help.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Okay, fine, you want to help. Then do what I did -- give them a semen sample.

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: I did, too. That’s a much more pleasant way to help.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If I’m not supposed to be a part of this thing, then why am I here? I look at my life and I... I’m a nobody. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now I connect the dots and see it’s all been leading me here. Why didn’t I become a doctor? Why did I downsize? Why did my wife abandon me? Dusan, how did you just happen to be my neighbor? Ngoc Lan, why were you the only one to survive that box and just happen to be cleaning Dusan’s place that day? And if you hadn’t lost your leg, I wouldn’t have tried to help you -- which, as usual, I screwed up. And why did I screw up? So I could wind up here at exactly the right time to go into that tunnel! I finally have the chance to do something that matters.

dialogues.speaker: DUSAN
dialogues.text: Paul, come on, you really are talking crazy. These people, they’re wonderful, but --

dialogues.speaker: KONRAD
dialogues.text: It’s like a cult.

dialogues.text: Take care of yourself.
